title.narrative: 107 PARTNERSHIPS FOR HUMAN.ACTION STRENG

description.narrative: Partnerships for humanitarian action strengthened and new partnerships are brokered to promote collaborative inclusive and well- coordinated approaches., which contributes to Saving Lives And Protecting Rights In Humanitarian Situations, United Nations Coherence And Cluster Coordination. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Timely, effective and reliable support is provided to country and regional offices to save lives and protect rights in humanitarian situations and to strengthen resilience

related-activity.ref: 456F/F0/09/100 TIMELY, EFFECTIVE AND RELIABLE SUPPORT I

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Partnerships for humanitarian action strengthened and new partnerships are brokered to promote collaborative inclusive and well-coordinated approaches.

description.narrative: In 2017, the work of IAHP focused in four areas: Global Partnerships, Inter-Agency work around major meetings, implementation of preparedness guidelines and improved early warning early action monitoring and information sharing and continued effective collaboration with stand-by partners in support of UNICEF Country Offices. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:11/01/2018

title.narrative: Within the framework of the existing MoU between UNICEF and IOM, initiate consultation with IOM in order to define key priority area for collaboration with the aim of developing more predictable partnerships and effective delivery of humanitarian action.

baseline.value: Existing MoU with IOM signed in 2006. Agreement in principle to revive the MoU with IOM with a focus on Humanitarian Action

target.value: 2016:a) Mapping of existing collaboration between the two agencies completed. b) Number of priority area and suggested way forward identified. c) Tentative plan of action developed.

actual.value: 2017:a)Review is ongoing and data is being collectedb)Target met - Specific project on making IOM Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) more child focused up and running - project manager seconded through standby. c)Target met - Annual consultation took place with IOM (Sept. 17) and action plan revised

title.narrative: Stronger systematic dialogue with WFP on bilateral operational and strategic issues for humanitarian response

baseline.value: No specific activity targeting WFP took place in 2015. d) In 2015, UNICEF has identified a partnership with IFRC/RC/RC.

target.value: 2016:a) 1 visit to WFP HQ to identify partnership opportunities b) 4 technical level meetings c) Engage with WFP on Humanitarian Financing (2 statements/letters/positions) d) Further contacts w/partners.

actual.value: 2017:a) Target met – a bilateral meeting on technical level was held with WFP in Rome to discuss the next steps in the partnershipb) Target met – UNICEF and WFP meet at a very regular basis in Geneva to discuss joint approachesc) Target met – UNICEF and WFP frequently discuss their positions on seve

title.narrative: Participation in IASC sessions and processes in line with UNICEF priorities.

baseline.value: UNICEF has participated and engaged in 100% of the IASC meetings.

target.value: 2016:UNICEF has participated and engaged in 100% of the IASC meetings

actual.value: 2017:Target met –UNICEF engaged in all IASC meetings. This engagement was done by the IAHP or with the support of the IAHP.

title.narrative: Management of stand-by relationships, including performance monitoring framework and structured planning process for UNICEF partners, expansion with empahsis on Global South, new agreements including service package developed

baseline.value: a) 152 deployments per year. Abandon rate between 12-19% per year. b) 67 Standby roster members trained. c) New database initial development. Draft service package agreement. 29 Standby Partners

target.value: 2016:a) 150 deployments Abandon rate <20%. b) 75 staff trained. Review of train. secretariat. c) Database operational. Perfor. Monitor. framework done. Service package agreem. cleared. 2 new partnership

actual.value: 2017:a)– Target met - 180 standby deployments - Target met - Abandon rate at 16% (lowest in three years despite 7 current L3s covering 14 COs and 1 RO - Consolidated surge proposal is presented as an option for the next OMP - Reviewed with DHR the STS Matrix and Surge Guidelines. b)– Target met - 5

title.narrative: Mapping of RO initiatives in South-South Cooperation, expansion of Map Your School project, Develop a cross-regional strategy on partnerships for 2015-17.

baseline.value: a) Agreement w/Govt Turkey on hold for signing. b) Prelim disc w/Cuba through CO. c) Draft on Business Children & Emergencies. d) Dialogue w/Knowledge Exchange & Horizontal Cooperation at DR

target.value: 2016:a) Standby Agreement signed with Turkey. b) Mission report with clear way forward identified. c) Potential for partnering w/PS fully investigated, if viable 1-2 partnership suggested way forward.

actual.value: 2017:a)Target not met due to external factors - Standby Agreement with Turkey on hold pending political changes in Turkish Government. b)Target met - Consultation took place with Argentina to explore potential standby partnership with Cascos Blancos - IAHP provided guidance to the CADRI team on how be

title.narrative: Sustained and substantial dialogue with humanitarian NGO partners on key themes to improve predictability of collaboration.

baseline.value: a) Consultations with NGOs on regular basis, as part of the IASC dialogue or within the clusters or other forum. b) PCA review completed and roll out to partner NGO completed, under FSG leadership.

target.value: 2016:a) Better and more predictable collaboration with humanitarian NGOs. b) First ever global consultation with CSO took place, including a humanitarian segment.

actual.value: 2017:a)Target met - Consultation with NGO taking place as need be (HI, NRC, IRC…).b)Target should be adjusted as it was decided that the global consultations will be organized by the CSO in New York

title.narrative: Inter-agency support to emergency response and preparedness through revision of ERP guidance, development of InfoRM, EW/EA reports of the IASC, inter-agency simulations

baseline.value: a) ERP materials & 2 trainings done b) 2 IASC EWEA meetings attended. 0 Risk List in 2015 c) UNICEF priorities in the IASC WP 2016-17 d) IA simulations e) Guidance in multi-risk shared at IA level

target.value: 2016:a) Attend 80% of IASC RG meetings. b) - Co-lead for IASC EWEAR. -11 Risk Lists. -Attend 80% of INFORM meetings. c) Engaged in all Gva Resilience work. d) Coordinating ERP with CADRI. e) Implement CFP

actual.value: 2017:a) Target met – UNICEF engaged in all IASC fora related to Risk, Early Warning and Preparedness.b) Target met – UNICEF participated in all IASC EWEA meetings - IAHP continues to produce risk products to ensure relevant inputs at inter-agency mechanisms and processes.- analytical capacity has be

title.narrative: Inter-agency mechanisms to implement preparedness activities, including CADRI and IASC TTPR

baseline.value: a) Fact sheet on the linkages between CFP, ERP and CADRI. b) National DRR work plan developed for at least 2 countries. c) CADRI partnership in at min 2 countries

target.value: 2016:a) Disclose of CADRI new Business Case with IASC. b) CADRI work plan, resource mobilization communication and regionalization strategy developed according to new BC. c) CADRI support to 3 COs/ROs.

actual.value: 2017:a) Target met - the CADRI business case has been widely shared with HQ and RO/COS. Communication, Knowledge management and regionalization strategies finalized.Implementation has been effective in 5 regions among which ECARO, WCARO, and ESARO, MENARO and LACRO and support provided in more than 20

title.narrative: A partnership between IFRC/RC/RC and UNICEF has been established and the program collaboration between UNICEF and IFRC/RC/RC has significantly increased.

baseline.value: a) Mapping of all collaborations and of collaborations. b) No participation yet. c) No joint advocacy yet. d) Meetings on both high level and technical level have taken place in 2015.

target.value: 2016:a) Mapping updated. of collaborations increased. b) UNICEF participated in 1BC. c) Communications issued. d) 4 meetings on senior technical level held and monthly meetings on technical level held.

actual.value: 2017:a)- Target met - All existing collaborations between UNICEF and IFRC/RC/RC have been mapped and all relevant documents were organized in folders- Target met – following the two workshops in 2016, the number of agreements between the IFRC and UNICEF has increased which has led to more children bein

title.narrative: UNHCR-UNICEF LOUs signed in refugee contexts, technical guidance notes in all priorirty sectors is developed, joint missions with UNHCR, structured dialogue at Executive level.

baseline.value: a) Mapping on UNHCR collaborations outdated. b) No missions or in-depth assessment done in 2015. c) In 2015, 2 high level meetings with UNHCR facilitated. 2 technical level meetings taken place.

target.value: 2016:a) Complete mapping updated database b) 2 field missions and reports to assess collaboration done c) 2 high level meetings organized. Good timely BN/NFR done. Quarterly technical level meetings.

actual.value: 2017:a) Target met – a mapping of all formal collaborations between UNICEF and INHCR on country level was madeb) Target met – a field mission to perform a joint UNICEF-UNHCR assessment of the protection and education needs of refugee children in Malaysia allowed to assess the collaboration between UNHC

title.narrative: Internalization of the TA through agreed inter-divisional workplan, inclusion of TA protocols in IRT simulations, communication from EMOPS and ED on TA progress, TA guidance available on UNICEF intranet

baseline.value: a) TA guidance systematically shared/on intranet. Including revised ERP training and PPTs. Intranet restructured, and fully updated b) Systematic engagement in the EDG and HNO/HRP meetings.

target.value: 2016:a) TA Intranet up to date and COs/ROs alerted. At request hold presentations/webinars on core elements of TA. b) 2 EDG meetings actively attended. Lessons Learned shared at EDG-Donor meetings.

actual.value: 2017:In 2017, the EDG informed the IASC members that following the WHS, the Transformative Agenda has been considered implemented.a) Target met – UNICEF's intranet page on the IASC is up to date and key documents are directly shared with relevant colleagues - Colleagues were given the possibility to pa

title.narrative: UNICEF support for system-wide improvements in humanitarian response, including missions, policy development, guidance revision.

baseline.value: a) UNICEF priorities in the IASC workplan 2016-17 b) UNICEF active engagement with partners re. meetings and WHS prep. c) Reported from humanitarian briefings and co-hosted 1 briefing.

target.value: 2016:a) UNICEF ‘s priorities reflected in IASC WG deliberations/subsidiary bodies' work. b) Engage with partners in all WHS meetings in Gva. c) Engaged in 75% of the hum briefings/co-hosted 2 briefings.

actual.value: 2017:a) Target met - UNICEF‘s priorities were mainstreamed in the inter-agency humanitarian policies, in the IASC workplan and in all reference groups/task teams. UNICEF was represented in all IASC meetings.b) Target met - UNICEF continuously engaged with humanitarian partners. c) Target partially me
